<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_:
```c
void
MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  /* Cache 'daemon' here to avoid data races */
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = connection->daemon;
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */
  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->urh);
  mhd_assert (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME));

  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
  connection->urh->was_closed = true;
  connection->resuming = true;
  daemon->resuming = true;
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
  if ( (MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (daemon->itc)) &&
       (! MHD_itc_activate_ (daemon->itc, "r")) )
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to signal resume via " \
                 "inter-thread communication channel.\n"));
#endif
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment in the function assigns to the parameter variable 'connection' itself. The only modifications are to objects referred to by that pointer (connection->urh->was_closed = true; connection->resuming = true), which is explicitly permitted by MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. The local pointer 'daemon' is a separate local variable (declared as 'struct MHD_Daemon *const') and is not the function parameter; modifying daemon->resuming alters the pointed-to object, which is allowed. There are no statements like 'connection = ...' or '*connection = ...' that would modify the parameter. The macro/assert and function calls (mhd_assert, MHD_mutex_lock_chk_, MHD_itc_activate_, etc.) do not show any assignment to the parameter in the provided code; even if they modify the object pointed to by connection, that is permitted by the rule. Therefore no fragments need investigation for Rule 17.8.
